nodes.text: Human information processing has a limited capacity for absolute judgments of unidimensional stimuli, commonly near seven alternatives (the 'magical number seven'), but this capacity can be extended by multidimensional stimuli, successive judgments, and recoding
Information theory provides a useful quantitative framework: amount of information corresponds to variance and transmitted information corresponds to input-output covariance or correlation
Method: Absolute judgment experiments measure channel capacity by increasing number of alternative stimuli and computing transmitted information in bits
Result: For unidimensional pitch judgments Pollack found transmitted information rises with input up to an asymptote at about 2.5 bits, corresponding to about six discriminable pitch categories

Result: Other unidimensional measures show similar channel capacities ranging roughly 1.6 to 3.9 bits (e.g., loudness 2.3 bits, taste concentration 1.9 bits, visual position 3.25-3.9 bits), mean about 2.6 bits (~6.5 categories)
Claim: Channel capacity for unidimensional stimuli is limited and fairly consistent across sensory attributes, implying a built-in limitation of perceptual or cognitive systems

Result: Adding independent stimulus dimensions increases channel capacity, but with diminishing returns; e.g., 2D dot-in-square 4.6 bits (about 24 categories) and six-dimension auditory stimuli produced about 7.2 bits (~150 categories)
Claim: Multidimensional stimuli allow simultaneous coarse judgments on multiple attributes, enabling much larger total identification capacity than single-dimension absolute judgments

Evidence: Pollack and Ficks found binary-judged multidimensional tones (six dimensions, five values each) yielded transmitted information 7.2 bits; other studies (e.g., Eriksen confounded attributes) show increased capacity when dimensionality increases

Result: Immediate memory (span of immediate memory) behaves differently: span is limited by number of chunks (about seven chunks) rather than bits per item; amount of information retained increases with bits per chunk

Evidence: Hayes and Pollack experiments varying stimulus types (binary digits, decimal digits, letters, words) show span in items is relatively constant while transmitted information increases with information per item, contradicting a constant-bits hypothesis
Claim: Absolute judgment span (bits-limited) and immediate memory span (chunk-limited) are distinct phenomena and should be conceptualized as limits on bits versus chunks respectively
Claim: Recoding (grouping input into larger chunks or using verbal or learned codes) increases bits per chunk and thereby effectively expands immediate memory capacity dramatically

Evidence: Smith and Sidney demonstrations show recoding binary sequences into larger-base groupings (octal, decimal) after training raises effective remembered binary digits from about 9 to 36-40 with sufficient practice

Conclusion: Human perceptual and mnemonic limits impose an informational bottleneck that is mitigated by multidimensional encoding, successive judgments (memory), and recoding strategies, and information theory offers a productive quantitative framework for studying these processes
